Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on . Due
to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective
action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed
or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In
the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at (616) 204-6992.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee Records
(1) An institution shall maintain employee
records for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time
specified in this rule.
(i) Documentation from the Michigan
department of human services, the equivalent
state or Canadian provincial agency, or
equivalent agency in the country where the

person usually resides, that the person has
not been determined to be a perpetrator of
child abuse or child neglect. The
documentation shall be completed not more
than 30 days prior to the start of employment
and every 12 months thereafter.
One of seven new employee files did not have the annual central registry
check run on the staff member's full legal name.
Repeat Violation Established
2022 Interim, CAP approved 9/15/2022
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee Records
(1) An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time
specified in this rule.
(f) A record of any convictions other than
minor traffic violations from either of the
following entities:
(ii) From an entity accessing either Michigan
state police records or equivalent state,
Canadian provincial, or other country law
enforcement agency where the person usually
resides or has resided in the previous 5 years.
One of seven new employee files did not have a criminal history check run on
the staff member's full legal name.
CCI Rule 400.4127 Staff to Resident Ratio
(4) When residents are asleep or otherwise
outside of the direct supervision of staff, staff
shall perform variable interval, eye-on checks of
residents. The time between the variable interval
c hecks shall not exceed fifteen minutes.
Multiple days during the period of review, interval checks for youth exceeded
15 minutes. In addition, interval checks are not being documented after third
shift ends, even if youth are in their rooms or still sleeping. The facility reports
they're being conducted, however, without proper documentation it is unknown
if they're occurring.

CCI Rule 400.4155 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter
care institutions; initial treatment plan.
(1) The social service worker shall complete, sign,
and date an initial treatment plan for each
resident within 30 calendar days of admission.
One of three open youth files had an initial treatment plan (ITP) that was not
completed within 30 days from admission. Youth's ITP was completed at 31
days.
CCI Rule 400.4156 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter
care institutions; updated treatment plan.
(5) The social service supervisor shall approve,
c ountersign, and date the updated treatment plan.
One of three open youth files and one of two closed youth files had initial
treatment plans and updated treatment plans that were not signed by the social
services supervisor. The acting case management supervisor was assigned as
the case manager for these three-youth due to low staffing, and his supervisor
did not review or sign off on the treatment plans. Instead, the case
management supervisor signed as the case manager and as the case
management supervisor for the reports he wrote.
CCI Rule 400.4167 Case Record Maintenance
(1) The institution shall maintain a case record for
e ach resident.
One of six active youth files reviewed had an updated treatment plan not
signed by the social services supervisor.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Dates for ISPs/USPs overlap rather than run consecutively. Please ensure one
date is not covered for two different reports (i.e., ISP ends 3/2/23 so USP should
begin on 3/3/23, not on 3/2/23).
• It is imperative files are kept up to date, in a safe location and in a uniform
manner. It is also important the tools and procedures the programs have in place
(i.e., quarterly file reviews) are being utilized consistently to ensure success.
• Ensure Human Resources has all required employee documents, so each
employee file is uniform and consistent.
V. CONSULTATION
• Supervisors or Managers could conduct random video footage reviews and
reviews on interval check logs to ensure checks are being conducted for youth at
intervals not to exceed 15-minutes and that the eyes-on checks are being
completed.

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were 1 substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period. Special Investigation 2023C0000203 dated 3/15/2023 found the facility in
non-compliance for rule 400.4158(1)(a)(ii) Interventions Standards & Prohibitions
and Rule 400.4112, Staff Qualifications. A corrective action plan, which included
additional training for staff, was approved on 4/10/2023. In addition, the agency
terminated one staff member and another staff member resigned. The facility’s
corrective action plan compliance is monitored quarterly. The agency has been in
compliance with meeting the expectations within their corrective action plan.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The
agency submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plan not related to maltreatment
during this licensing period. The facility’s corrective action plan was a result of their
2022 interim audit inspection. The violations found during the interim inspection
included a central registry check not being completed within 30 days of hire for a
new staff, an employee evaluation not being completed within 180 days for a new
staff, a staff member not receiving 16 hours of orientation prior to assuming duties
of the position, a clothing inventory not being completed for one youth, and a youth
file lacking a medical exam within 30 days of admission, The agency's corrective
action plan was approved on 9/15/22. The agency demonstrated compliance with
the corrective action plan as there were no repeat issues during the period of
review for this renewal inspection. Although Rule 400.4113(1)(i) is considered a
repeat violation, the circumstances surrounding the violation are not the same.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the facility's
budget and the agency's financial audit.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
Not Applicable.
Chief Administrator Assessment
Chief Administrator (CA) noted the tools and processes they put in place because
of the 2022 interim inspection corrective action plan have been working. CA noted
the most difficult situation during the period of review was the discovery of mold in
the program and the subsequent transfer of the youth to another licensed CCI. CA
noted repairs and construction are ongoing and they anticipate the project will be
completed by the end of October 2023. CA reported there have been no
unplanned discharges during the period of review. CA reported the agency
conducts regular team meetings to review policies/procedures, receive specialized
training on a variety of topics, adjust necessary programming and ensure quality
service at all levels.

Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff interviews were conducted during the onsite inspection. Staff reported low
staffing has created some tension, but overall, they are a great team and feel they
work well as a unit. Staff reported their direct supervisors are very supportive, but
they do not feel as much support from upper management. Staff noted upper
management makes a lot of demands, but aren't onsite or talking to staff to learn
about their daily work, barriers, etc. Staff would like more transparency from upper
management related to budgetary concerns, staff wages and lay-offs/staffing
changes at the Bethany Christian Services company level. Staff feel the wages
aren't competitive for the work being conducted and feel it's unfair staff who have
worked for the agency for years are receiving close to or the same wages as
brand-new staff. Staff noted this creates resentment as seasoned staff are doing
more work and have more responsibilities since they are training new staff.
Despite these concerns, it is apparent staff love their jobs, love working with the
youth, and want to continue to be there to support the youth during their stay at the
agency.
Youth interviews were conducted during the onsite inspection. Youth reported the
transition from Casa Del Sol's location to Bridgeway's location has been difficult as
they do not have as much freedom. They reported they are excited to go back to
Casa Del Sol's location within the next couple months. The youth feel the staff
treat them well and they have no complaints about interactions with staff. The
youth who go to temple would like to go more often, but low staffing has not
allowed them to. They would like to see staffing improve so they are able to go on
more outings. Some youth also noted they would like to personally take more trips
to pick out and purchase food to satisfy their cultural needs.
Description of Agency Walk Through
An onsite inspection at the agency's temporary location at CCI Bridgeway's third
floor on 8/25/23 was completed and no concerns were noted. Casa Del Sol has
been temporarily operating out of Bridgeway's location due to a mold issue
causing everyone to relocate from Casa Del Sol's location due to repairs and
construction required. It is anticipated the construction and repairs will be finished
by the end of October 2023. As a result of the construction, a fire inspection and
an environmental health inspection are unable to be completed at Casa Del Sol's
location prior to the expiration of the license. A variance was approved on 9/8/23
for Rules R 400.4101-R 400.4568 and it is expected the inspections will be
completed no later than 11/1/2023.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
